senses.de: To repeat the exact words that someone else has said or written.
senses.ex: He quoted a line from her favorite book.

Tips.title: Exact Repetition
Tips.description: Use 'quote' to show you are using somebody's exact words, not paraphrasing.
Tips.example: In his speech, he quoted the president verbatim.

Tips.title: Attribution Necessary
Tips.description: When quoting, always give credit to the original speaker or writer.
Tips.example: She quoted Shakespeare, saying 'To be, or not to be...'

senses.de: To give someone an estimated cost for a job or service.
senses.ex: He quoted me $500 for the repair work.

Tips.title: Preliminary Cost
Tips.description: Quote as a verb in business means giving an initial estimate, not the final price.
Tips.example: They quoted me an initial fee for the event planning.

Tips.title: No Commitment
Tips.description: A price quote is usually no obligation, meaning it's not a binding contract.
Tips.example: I asked for a quote but haven't decided to purchase yet.

Tips.title: Changeable Rates
Tips.description: The quoted price can change based on final details or requirements.
Tips.example: The initial quote was low, but the price increased with extra features.

senses.de: A phrase or passage from a book, speech, etc. that someone repeats, usually because it is interesting or useful.
senses.ex: He is known for his funny quotes.

Tips.title: Memorable Wisdom
Tips.description: Quotes are often memorable sayings that offer advice or wisdom.
Tips.example: His grandfather's quote became his life mantra.

Tips.title: Cultural Impact
Tips.description: Quotes from influential figures often reflect cultural values or history.
Tips.example: The quote from Dr. King resonated with many.

Tips.title: Context Matters
Tips.description: Understand the context to fully appreciate the meaning of a quote.
Tips.example: Her favorite quote was more impactful when she learned its history.

senses.de: A price that a person or company says they will do a piece of work for.
senses.ex: Could you send me a quote for the necessary repairs?

Tips.title: Service Comparison
Tips.description: Use quotes to compare costs between different service providers.
Tips.example: I gathered several quotes before choosing a contractor.

Tips.title: Budget Planning
Tips.description: Quotes help you plan expenses for a project or purchase.
Tips.example: Getting a quote helped me budget for the home renovation.

Cite.wordDefinition:
Both cite and quote are used to refer to referencing a source, but they have different meanings.

Cite means to refer to or mention a source, such as a book or a website, in order to provide evidence or further support for an argument.

For example, if you were writing an essay on climate change, you might cite a report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change to support your argument.

Cite refers to referencing a source, while quote refers specifically to repeating someone else's words exactly.

Extract.wordDefinition:
Extract means to take out or remove a portion from a larger whole, while quote means to repeat or use someone else's words verbatim.

For example, if a person reads a long book and wants to use a small section in a report, they would extract (take out) that section from the book.

Both words can also be used in different contexts, but generally, extract refers to taking out a part of something while quote refers to using someone else's words exactly as they were said or written.

Mention.wordDefinition:
Mention means to briefly refer or talk about something without providing any exact words or phrases. It is applicable when you want to give a general idea or reference something in passing.

For example, "He mentioned that he was thinking of getting a new car."

Note.wordDefinition:
A note is a brief piece of writing that contains information about something.

It can be a reminder or a short explanation. For example, you might write a note to remind yourself to buy milk.

A note is a short message or reminder while a quote is a word-for-word repetition of someone else's statement in order to support or illustrate a point.

Paraphrase.wordDefinition:
Paraphrasing means rewording someone else's words or ideas in your own words while still conveying the same meaning. It is applicable when you want to explain someone's ideas by using your own language.

A good paraphrase is not identical to the original text but retains its meaning.

Recite.wordDefinition:
Recite means to repeat something out loud from memory, like reciting a poem or a pledge. For example, "I can recite the entire Pledge of Allegiance by heart.".

Quote is used when one repeats exact words written by someone else, while recite is used when one repeats something from memory out loud.

Refer.wordDefinition:
Refer means to mention a source or give credit to where you found the information. For example, "According to a recent study by the American Medical Association, regular exercise improves mental health.".

In short, we use quote when we want to include someone's exact words, while we use refer when we want to acknowledge the source of information.

Reiterate.wordDefinition:
Reiterate means to repeat or emphasize something that has already been said or done. This is usually done to make sure that the person you are speaking to remembers something important, or to emphasize a point.

To put it simply, quote means repeating someone else's exact words, while reiterate means repeating or emphasizing something that has already been said.

Repeat.wordDefinition:
Repeat means to say or do something again, usually without any changes or alterations. It is applicable when you want to reiterate or echo something that has already been said or done, or when you want to copy something exactly without necessarily giving credit to the original source.

In summary, quoting involves copying someone else's exact words and giving credit to the original source, while repeating involves saying or doing something again without necessarily giving credit or acknowledgment to the original source.

quotes.Text: There's something about being any kind of entertainer that is acting. You have to put on a show. Things you wouldn't do in your life, you do on stage. You have to let go. And that's extra hard for rappers. We have a tendency to, quote unquote, keep it real. As an actor, you have to be able to humiliate yourself. Do whatever it takes.
quotes.Title: Jamaican Musician
quotes.Name: Heavy D

quotes.Text: I've always been able to hear and read what I say before I say it. That's why I'm a good quote. Or a good interview. If I say something that's uncomfortable for someone's ears, it's going to be the truth; I just happen to voice it. But it's the truth. It's not my opinion.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Reggie Jackson

quotes.Text: There are people who are bound journalistically to a code of ethics that means they can't quote something that isn't sourced, whereas what I do is entirely unsourced. I effectively fictionalise history and yet somehow aim at a greater truth.
quotes.Title: British Writer
quotes.Name: Peter Morgan

quotes.Text: At the beginning of a new project, often before I do any actual writing, I collect photos, quotes, song lyrics, and even objects that relate to the characters or the world I'm creating.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Kami Garcia

quotes.Text: If we took information only from sources with which we agreed on all issues, we would be left with merely quoting ourselves, and we would miss a great deal of truth.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: G. Edward Griffin

quotes.Text: Have you ever observed that we pay much more attention to a wise passage when it is quoted than when we read it in the original author?
quotes.Title: English Artist
quotes.Name: Philip Gilbert Hamerton

quotes.Text: One of the difficulties of a job in the, quote, 'real world' is you don't really get time to shut yourself off in a room and think.
quotes.Title: Indian Economist
quotes.Name: Raghuram Rajan

quotes.Text: The biggest problem I have in journalism is being quoted or misquoted and then being asked to defend something I haven't said.
quotes.Title: British Journalist
quotes.Name: Robert Fisk

quotes.Text: One must be a wise reader to quote wisely and well.
quotes.Title: American Educator
quotes.Name: Amos Bronson Alcott
